awd_titl_txt: Folding and Mechanical Response of Single Proteins Probed at High Spatio-Temporal Resolution
awd_abstract_narration:
Proteins are essential to life. For humans to walk, hear, or touch, proteins must generate and respond to forces after folding into their correct three-dimensional structure. Yet, traditional biochemical techniques do not measure a protein's response to force, hindering progress in the emerging field of mechanobiology. Inside a cell, force can induce subtle change in a protein's structure, fully unfold a protein, or disrupt the interaction between two proteins. These effects all have biological consequence. To exert a force on individual proteins and measure these tiny signals, this project will use novel atomic force microscope (AFM) cantilevers, which are micron-scale, diving-board like force sensors. This project will help elucidate the response of proteins to force, a critical but understudied signaling mechanism in biology. More generally, studying the process of protein folding with these novel cantilevers will provide insight into how proteins fold, an ongoing challenge despite five decades of effort. By using the tools of physics and nanoscience to solve exciting problems in biology, this project will provide excellent interdisciplinary training for high school and colleges students just starting their research career. As statistics are vital to interpreting experiments but are poorly understood by many young researchers, this project will also generate novel training tools focused on statistics and data analysis using biological examples. These interactive education simulations will be developed in conjunction with the CU-Boulder PhET program and thereby leverage their expertise in such simulations and world-wide distribution.

The twin scientific goals are (i) to characterize structural transitions in two widely studied mechano-sensitive proteins, titin's I27 domain and the focal adhesion kinase, since previous studies have either yielded conflicting results or failed to resolve a predicted mechanically induced transition; and (ii) measure a model two-state protein's folding transition time with 1-microsecond resolution. The key technical hurdle is that traditional AFM studies lack the spatial precision to resolve subtle changes in protein structure and lack the temporal precision to characterize the conformational dynamics of a traditional globular protein during the brief time the protein moves along its transition path. This project will overcome these obstacles by applying a state-of-the-art combination of force precision, stability, and time resolution enabled by focused-ion beam modification of AFM cantilevers. 

This project is jointly funded by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Physics of Living Systems Program in the Division of Physics.

por.por_cntn:
Atomic force microscopy (AFM)-based single-molecule force spectroscopy enables an array of studies, from measuring the strength of a ligand-receptor bond to elucidating the complex unfolding pathway of membrane proteins. Such studies and the diverse applications of AFM across biophysics and nanotechnology are improved by enhancing the force stability, force precision, and time resolution of bioAFM. During this grant, we dramatically improved the performance of AFM-based force spectroscopy on a commercial AFM using a focused ion beam to micromachine AFM cantilevers. Our most recent cantilever design achieved a >10-fold improvement in force precision (0.2 pN) and a ~100-fold improvement in time resolution (8 μs) in liquid, a significant advance over the traditional bioAFM performance (~5-20 pN and ~1 ms, respectively).

Scientific Impact: These technical advances were applied to a diverse range of biological systems including model three-helix bundles, bacterial proteins that enhance virulence, model membrane proteins, a RNA hairpin from HIV, and a computationally designed protein-ligand complex, a few of which are highlighted below.

Gram-negative bacteria utilize the Type III Secretion System, a syringe-like nanomachine, to inject "effector" proteins directly into the cytosol of host cells, subverting their defense mechanisms and facilitating infection. Effector proteins must be unfolded at the base of the syringe prior to secretion. However, fusion of well folded proteins such as green fluorescent protein (GFP) to effector proteins inhibits secretion because the unfoldase is incapable of unfolding such tightly folded proteins. This observation led to the paradigm that effector proteins have low thermodynamic stability. In collaborative work, we first showed that two effector proteins with well characterized secretion kinetics have typical thermodynamic stabilities, on par with GFP. We then showed effector proteins are among the most mechanically labile proteins characterized to date by AFM. Our analysis of mechanical-unfolding data shows that they unfold at very low forces and have long distances to the unfolding transition state. Both features facilitate unfolding. This work provided a new paradigm for what makes effector proteins secretable.

We also advanced techniques to characterize the energetics of membrane protein folding by developing a method to measure the free-energy change of point-mutants (ΔΔG) in membrane protein using AFM. Traditional ΔΔG studies using chemical-denaturation in detergent micelles help form the foundation of the field's knowledge of membrane-protein energetics. However, chemical-denaturation assays are limited in their biological applicability. They cannot be performed in lipid bilayers, and are thus insensitive to native side-chain--lipid interactions. Moreover, their scope is limited. They are only applicable to a tiny subset of membrane proteins that reversibly globally refold in denaturant. These limitations motivated our approach based on local reversible mechanical unfolding of individual proteins in their native lipid bilayer using AFM. Thermodynamic quantities were precisely measured by extensive sampling of near-equilibrium unfolding/refolding transitions of individual proteins. We showed quantitative agreement with prior chemical denaturation for a particular point mutation (L223A) that probes a protein-protein interaction, adding credence to the existing ΔΔG literature. However, we saw disagreement with SDS-derived values for V217A, a mutant that probes a protein-lipid interaction, raising the important point that chemical-denaturation experiments performed in detergent micelles are not sensitive to critical protein-lipid interactions present in native lipid bilayers.

Single-molecule force spectroscopy studies of RNA folding using optical traps have yielded numerous scientific insights, including kinetic rate constants, energetics, intermediate states, and folding pathways. Such scientific success is predicated on a triumvirate of metrological requirements (force precision, stability, and time resolution) that hinders broader adoption due to the technical challenges in building, operating, and housing custom optical traps. We circumvented these challenges by developing a high-precision assay for characterizing RNA folding implemented on a commercial AFM, quantifying the dynamics of an RNA hairpin from HIV. We then reconstructed the full 1D free-energy landscape for folding, a first for this hairpin and the first by AFM for any structured nucleic acid. Such reconstructions remain the pinnacle of the force-spectroscopy field and achieved for only few select nucleic-acid structures (or proteins) and by a handful of leading labs when using state-of-the-art optical traps.

Broader impacts: Participation in this project for all group members was an outstanding educational experience because of its multi-disciplinary nature. Like many issues being addressed by future employers (e.g., national labs, academia, and industry), the challenges addressed in this grant required expertise beyond a single discipline. Team members---4 post-docs, 3 graduate students, 5 undergraduates, and 1 high school student---developed a diverse skill set (e.g., biological sample preparation, operation of an advanced AFM, statistical analysis, and scientific communication). Broadening STEM participation of under-represented minority k-8 students in STEM was enhanced by inquiry-based science activities in a playful, engaging, and welcoming environment in conjunction with lab tours. Public lectures at the Wheeler Opera house in Aspen, including Nobel Laureate Art Ashkin, were organized as part of the biennial Single Molecule Biophysics meeting co-organized by the PI.
